bibl.title: Letter from Mollie Acker to Henry Rose Carter, December 14, 1924

div1.p: Acker writes about Carter's book and provides news of her family.

div1.head: Letter from Mollie Acker to Henry Rose Carter, December 14, 1924

opener.dateline:
406 PEASHWAY STREET
HARTER HEIGHTS
SOUTH BEND, INDIANA
Sunday - Dec. 14. 24.

div1.p:
Christmas here again
and how are you. How often during
the year Bob and I have thought
of you and spoken of you and hoped
that you were better. It is wonderful
that you have been able to do so
much, even though often in pain. Bob
was most interested in all the
special work and writing you have
been doing. If you have been able to
add to the book I know you will
feel more satisfied but it must be
particularly hard to want to do so
much when you know that rest is
imperative and essential. We were so
very glad to get your letter. I am
afraid though that it was a great
effort to write 'and it would be better
for you not to attempt to answer
this. Laura will perhaps send us
a few lines after Christmas, with a
few messages from you, and just
let us know how you are.

We seem fairly content at the end
of our second year in South Bend.
Bob has been practising by himself
this past year - which is better in
every way. He has a tidy practice
and is well liked but the industrial
406 PEASHWAY STREET
HARTER HEIGHTS
SOUTH BEND, INDIANA
depression everywhere has made it rather
bad for doctors. Especially here, where
the entire population is dependent upon
the various industries the financial
slump has been very marked. Studebakers
Oliver Ploughs. Singer Sewing Machines &
Wilson Shirts - all have huge plants and
were all closed at once. We never
knew by whistles, when it might be
Seven a.m. We are hoping for this
coming year to be better and in the
meantime, though I am chief cook and
bottle washer, I am getting fat on the
job and only bewail the fact that I
have so little time to feed my poor
dusty brain. In as much as my mother
learned to speak French & German after
she was fifty, there may yet be time
for me.

Your little Gwenyth is well - big
Gwenyth I should say, for she grows so
tall and slim. She is pale and has no
great resistance but manages to hold
her own. She is wonderfully advanced
at school in all subjects, and even
skipped most of her second grade so
that she is now in the last half of
third grade and only 7 1/2 yrs old. She
remembers long verses of poetry in a
most astounding way. Young Bobbie is
a bundle of health and high spirits
406 PEASHWAY STREET
HARTER HEIGHTS
SOUTH BEND, INDIANA
does not know any of his A. B. C's &
thinks only of trains & autos, and things
he can do with his hands.

We often wish we could come to
see you but our hands seem to be tied.
We were glad to have news of the
Derivaux and also of Dr. Luizon whom
Bob knows quite well.

I hope your Christmas will be a
happy one, and the coming year kind
to you. We send our best wishes to
Laura too and thank her for so kindly
sending your letters to us.

Gwenyth sends
her love to
“The Man”
